title: A Life of Service
devotional:
Old Mr. Abernathy lived a simple life. He never amassed great wealth, nor did he achieve widespread fame. His home was a modest cottage on the edge of town, his days filled with quiet routines. But what most people didn't realize was that Mr. Abernathy possessed a wealth far greater than money or recognition – a heart overflowing with service.

Every morning, before the town stirred, he'd clear the snow from the sidewalks of his elderly neighbors. He’d mend fences for those too frail to manage. His garden, though small, yielded a bounty of vegetables which he freely shared with anyone in need. He visited the local nursing home weekly, not to preach or boast, but simply to listen, to hold hands, and to offer a comforting presence. He tutored children after school, sharing his love of reading and helping them unlock their potential. He volunteered at the soup kitchen, washing dishes and offering a kind word to those who came seeking nourishment.

Mr. Abernathy never sought praise or reward. His service was a quiet, unassuming act of love. He saw needs and met them, driven by a deep-seated belief that every act of kindness, no matter how small, made a difference. One day, a young woman, observing his tireless efforts, asked him, "Mr. Abernathy, why do you do so much for others? What do you get out of it?"

He smiled gently and replied, "My dear, I've learned that true happiness isn't found in what we accumulate for ourselves, but in what we give away. Service isn't a burden, it's a blessing. It's a way to connect with others, to share God's love, and to make the world a little brighter, one act at a time." Mr. Abernathy's life was a testament to the transformative power of service. It wasn’t about grand gestures, but about the daily, consistent acts of kindness that rippled outward, touching countless lives.
image_description: A snow-covered pathway leading to a cozy cottage with smoke rising from the chimney, surrounded by snow-laden trees.
insights: Jesus exemplified a life of service, famously washing the feet of his disciples (John 13:1-17). This act, performed by a servant, demonstrated the humility and selflessness that should characterize Christian leadership and discipleship. He stated, 'For even the Son of Man did not come to be served, but to serve, and to give his life as a ransom for many' (Mark 10:45). This passage underscores the sacrificial nature of true service and its ultimate purpose in bringing redemption to others. Romans 12:13 encourages us to 'Share with the Lord’s people who are in need. Practice hospitality,' highlighting the practical ways we can extend service to those around us.
prayer: Heavenly Father, open my eyes to the needs around me. Grant me a heart willing to serve, not for recognition or reward, but out of genuine love for You and for others. Help me to see service not as a burden, but as a privilege and a blessing. Empower me to make a difference in the lives of those I encounter each day, through small acts of kindness and compassion. In Jesus’ name, Amen.
reflection: Reflect on Mr. Abernathy's life. What are some small, practical ways you can incorporate service into your daily routine? Is there someone in your life who could benefit from your act of kindness? How can you shift your perspective to view service as a blessing rather than an obligation?
